title: Amazon Makes Early Wins as Emmys Begin
text:
Amazon logged multiple early victories at the 71st Emmy Awards on Sunday night, with wins for its comedies “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel ” and “Fleabag.”

Phoebe Waller-Bridge, the creator and star of the darkly comic “Fleabag,” won her first Emmy awards, including a big one: outstanding lead actress in a comedy series. She also earned a win for writing the series.

Harry Bradbeer described Ms. Waller-Bridge as a “glorious grenade” while accepting the award for directing a comedy series.

“Mrs. Maisel” star Alex Borstein, who plays the manager of the stand-up comedian at the center of the show, took home the supporting actress award for the second year in a row. Tony Shaloub won best supporting actor, his fourth Emmy, for his role as the high-strung father.

Last year “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,” set in the New York comedy scene of the 1950s and ’60s, took home the award for outstanding comedy series.

Operating on Fox without a host this year, the awards show opened with an appearance by Homer Simpson and transitioned into a moment of self-congratulation, with Bryan Cranston intoning: “Television has never been bigger. Television has never mattered more. And television has never been this damn good.”

“Game of Thrones” was on track to break a record the dragon-fueled fantasy show had previously set, in 2015, for the most single-year awards for a series. “Veep” was looking for its fourth win for outstanding comedy series, having won for its last three seasons.

Comparing the annual Emmy haul by HBO and Netflix is at least one way to keep score of the competition between TV’s old and new guard. HBO went into this year’s Emmys leading all networks with 137 total nominations, while Netflix went into voting with 118 nominations. The two outlets tied for total wins in 2018.

With a full-tilt campaign strategy, Netflix had nominations across categories, but the streamer was forced to observe in recent years as direct rivals became the first streamers to win best drama series (Hulu’s “The Handmaid’s Tale”) and best comedy series (Amazon’s “Mrs. Maisel”).

description: Comedies ‘Fleabag’ and ‘The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ gain awards as show opens
